DOC.HEAD: Nicotine Helps Alzheimer's Patients
Eds: SUBS 2nd graf `Giving nicotine' to restore dropped title. Picks up 3rd, `Research carried ...'
DOC.TEXT: Nicotine, the drug inhaled by cigarette smokers, can help reduce the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease, psychologists reported Tuesday. ``Giving nicotine resulted in the patients becoming more alert, responding more vigorously, and doing better on a variety of mental tests,'' Reading University psychology professor David Warburton told the London conference of the British Psychological Society. Research carried out at London University's Institute of Psychiatry by Warburton's colleagues, Dr. Barbara Sahakian and Gemma Jones, matched 39 Alzheimer's patients with a healthy group of elderly people of the same age and intellectual ability. Compared with the effects of a placebo, nicotine helped the patients suffering from premature senile dementia symptoms associated with Alzheimer's to be more alert, the psychologists said. However, they said nicotine did not improve their memories. Alzheimer's is a progressive disease characterized by degeneration of the brain cells. Warburton said he would not prescribe cigarettes to his patients. ``My colleagues and I have never at any time recommended patients smoke cigarettes,'' the psychologist said. ``We were experimenting with safe ways of giving nicotine, for example through a specially impregnated patch on the skin.'' Warburton's report was one of 150 papers presented at the two-day conference held at London University's Institute of Education.
